Documentation
Plugin installation
Allows the developer to install a plugin, using the CLI.
Basic usage
Considering you want to install a plugin named content-manager you can run the following command:
$ strapi install content-manager.
This supposed that this plugin is published on the npm registry as strapi-plugin-content-manager.
The command installs the plugin in the node_modules folder of your Strapi application, and then, move the plugin itself in the ./plugins folder, so you can edit it and version it.
Development mode
In order to make contributors life easier, a command is dedicated to development mode:
$ strapi install plugin-name --dev (eg. $ strapi install content-manager --dev)
This command creates a symlink between the Strapi application and the plugin, which should have been previously installed globally ($ npm link or $ npm install plugin-name -g).
Plugin uninstallation
Allows the developer to uninstall a plugin, using the CLI.
Basic usage
Command: $ strapi uninstall plugin-name (eg. $ strapi uninstall content-manager).
This command simply removes the plugin folder.

Make the administration panel a real front-end app without any backend dependency. Remove the Admin.js controller. Remove the Admin.js service. Remove routes and use public core middleware to serve the administration panel instead. Documentation On every start, the files ./admin/admin/src/config.plugins.json is generated based on the installed plugins. The file should look like this: [ { "id": "content-type-builder", "source": { "development": "http://localhost:1337/admin/content-type-builder/main.js", "production": "http://localhost:1337/admin/content-type-builder/main.js", "test": "http://localhost:1337/admin/content-type-builder/main.js" } } ] This file is also included and minified in the build. This file indicates to the admin what are the plugins that need to be initialized and their sources URLs to require them. Note: The administration panel will choose the source based on the environment build. Host the admin and plugins on another server/CDN If your administration is hosted on another server than your Strapi project, you need to re-build the admin with the new configuration. Note: We highly recommend to start your server before launching the build to ensure the ./admin/admin/src/config/plugins.json is up-to-date. ./config/environment/**/server.json { "host": "localhost", "port": 1337, "autoReload": { "enabled": true }, "cron": { "enabled": false }, "admin": { "path": "/dashboard", "build": { "host": "http://admin.myapp.com", "backend": "http://api.myapp.com:8080", "plugins": { "source": "host", "folder": "/plugins" } } } } path (string): Allow to change the URL to access the admin (default: /admin). build host (string): URL to access the admin panel (default: http://localhost:1337/admin). backend (string): URL that the admin panel and plugins will request (default: http://localhost:1337). plugins source (origin, remote, custom): More details below. folder (string): More details below. Source The source setting allows you to define the URLs to require to plugins in the admin panel. Three modes are available host will use the host setting to generate the source URL for the plugins (example: http://admin.myapp.com/**/main.js). origin will use the origin URL. It means the default host and port (example: http://localhost:1337/**/main.js). custom will use the source defined in each ./plugins/**/config/sources.json file. Based on the previous configurations file, it will generate the following index.html to require the shared dependencies vendor.dll.js and the plugins.
Folder For example, if you decide to put your admin panel and plugins builds on an AWS S3 server, your files structure could like that: - src/ - 0bd35bad03d09ca61ac6cce225112e36.svg - 1d51d8767683a24635702f720cda4e26.svg - af3aefd0529349e40e4817c87c620836.png - config/ - plugins.json - main.js - main.js.map - plugins/ - content-type-builder/ - 0bd35bad03d09ca61ac6cce225112e36.svg - 1d51d8767683a24635702f720cda4e26.svg - af3aefd0529349e40e4817c87c620836.png - main.js - main.js.map - vendor.dll.js - vendor.dll.js.map The folder setting allows you to tell to the admin panel that the plugins are in a sub-folder named plugins. Host the plugins on another servers/CDN It allows you to override the generated source URL per environment. This feature is useful if you decide to host your build on AWS S3, etc. ./plugins/**/config/sources.json { "sources": { "production": "http://s3.aws.com/xxxx/main.js", "test": "http://s3.aws.com/test/xxxx/main.js" } } So the ./admin/admin/src/config.plugins.json will look like this: [ { "id": "content-type-builder", "source": { "development": "http://localhost:1337/admin/content-type-builder/main.js", "production": "http://s3.aws.com/xxxx/main.js", "test": "http://s3.aws.com/test/xxxx/main.js" } } ]

The problem was that the relation was recreated on only one side and sometimes, the removal of the previous relationship was executed before updating with the new one (because of the asynchronous function) and if the relation remained the same, that's why sometimes the relation disappears.
So there are the steps :

Delete relation on the old first side (if exists)
Delete relation on the old second side
Recreate relation on the new first side (only when deletion complete)
Recreate relation on the new second side (only when deletion complete and if value not null)

MySQL 5.7 is more strict than previous versions for dates as it requires a default value.
While installing contentajs with MySQL I had to manually run a few SQL queries. Some of them failed with the following error:
sql> CREATE TABLE `upload_file` (
  id INT AUTO_INCREMENT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
  name text,
  hash text,
  ext text,
  mime text,
  size text,
  url text,
  provider text,
  updated_at timestamp,
  created_at timestamp
)
[2018-04-18 08:14:09] [42000][1067] Invalid default value for 'created_at'

I had to adjust these timestamp fields so they define default values. After doing so I was able to run strapi start and view the homepage in the browser.
See https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/sql-mode.html#sqlmode_no_zero_in_date for details.

My PR is a üêõ Bug fix that SSO didn't work in some environment, though it worked on the React example in the initial phase.
Main update on the Plugin
Problems and fixes
The SSO works on initial registration but not on re-login
In the React SSO example project I could login with Microsoft account for the first time, but not for the second time.
There were two places that caused this bug
No provider in the user model
while the provider service uses user.provider to decide if the user already exists or not, the model doesn't have provider field anymore hence, it always think the user exists but it's not registered with the requested provider resulting to respond Auth.form.error.email.taken error.
The provider was somehow removed in this commit: 688defc#diff-18cc44092da248f6a77fa8e1c3840153
I re-added provider field: 17d5e29
Bootstrap code of content manager mutates global strapi model
After I added provider in the model, somehow the user data which was created by registration via SSO still lacked provider field. After adding a few break points, I found the bootstrap code in content manager mutates the global strapi.models object.
I fixed this particular bug in the following commit:  4beab15
Though the commit fixed the issue that I was experiencing, I worry that we may have similar bugs somewhere in the module as we mutate objects here and there. I think it's good to refactor so that it doesn't mutate objects, but probably in another PR.
### SSO didn't work when Strapi app is hosted in https server
I found that the callback URL which Strapi sends to SSO auth server always starts with http even when it's hosted on https server. That's because the protocol was hardcoded to 'http'. I found a few more places where http was hardcoded, but I fixed only the part where SSO matters because that's what I could test.
I fixed it in the following commit:
12cc6d6
I assumed that process.env.PROTOCOL would be a good place to set whether the server is 'http' or 'https', but let me know if you prefer different variable.
There is another bug that the actual callback URL that Strapi sends to SSO auth server is different from what user can see from the settings screen, but this isn't blocking user to use SSO and can be fixed in another PR, I guess.
